Am Gaumen ein tolles Wechselspiel zwischen dem Malz und den Zitrusnoten. Gehaltvoll und beinah erfrischend gleichzeitig. Ich liebe diese s√§uerlichen Noten! Nicht sonderlich viele R√∂staromen; leichte Holz- und Vanillearomen. Sehr komplex! Absolut gro√üartiges Bier. Sehr langes Finale mit einer wunderbaren S√º√ü/Sauer/Bitter-Balance. Ganz nah an der Perfektion. Eines dieser (seltenen) Biere, die am Gaumen mehr preisgeben, als an der Nase. F√ºr mich bislang eines der besten Biere, die ich getrunken habe - auch besser als das "normale" Pannepot und das Reserva.

Not bad but regular Pannepot is far better.  This kind of just lost flavor/carbonation from the original and left a much flatter spicy watered down version of the original, which still tastes good but compared to the original falls flat.

2005 Vintage.  The label says 1 pt 9.4 fl oz, but this is obviously a 330 or so ml bottle.  Pours a deep brown that allows no light to pass with clear transparent brown edges.  There is a thin-moderate creamy light brown head that lingers until mid-glass and leaves partial lace.  Very pleasant aroma of oak, malt, vanilla, dates, figs and just a bit of molasses.  The flavor is malt and oak with malty sweetness along with some dates and figs.  The flavor of the scotch emerges towards the finish and is somewhat boozey.  Mild bitterness at the finish.  Medium-full bodied and well-rounded on the palate.  Very enjoyable.

1/21/12. 2008 version on tap. Hazy dark brown with a nice big, fluffy khaki head that sticks and laces a bit. Rich aroma of Belgian yeast, dark fruits, bubblegum, and juuuust a touch of sour. Nice sweet flavor of dark fruits, brown sugar, yeast, and another small dash of sour. Nice!
Pour is a heady amber copper with a sticky white head. Smell is figgy dry ashy. Taste is toasted raisons sweet malts thick delicious mouthful that really sells this beer.

2008 version On tap at Avenue pub. Pours a cloudy brown woth a large creamy beige head leaving sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is roasted malt and caramel. Thin mouthfeel with a rich chocolate flavor and sweet malt finish. Hides alcohol well, a very impressive Belgian strong ale from De Struise.
Spicier than the reg reserva,  nearly three years of barrel aging really beat up the original beer is pretty beat up but the nuances are cool. The original beer was so amazing.

Aroma is much the same as standard Pannepot, but with a little oak and more apparent coffee. Appearance is black with light tan head. Flavor is quite muted, with some dark fruits and coffee; I noticed the alcohol here, which I did not with the 2010 Pannepot. Palate is bubbly and chewy. Still excellent, but I liked the regular Pannepot a little more.

Dark brown color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, some oak, caramel, dark fruit, & light vanilla; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, yeast, oak, caramel, chocolate, dark fruit (notably plums & dates), raisons, spice, and some licorice; Finish is dry; Nicely balanced & complex; Tastes like a stout at this point - very good overall.

2005 vintage.  I can¬ít believe I haven¬ít had this until now.  Pours to a super dark brown body that looks nearly black.  A creamy lively light tan head sits on top.  Aromas of light chocolate malt, raisins, prunes, Belgian yeasts, dust, and subtle green apple.  The flavor is hay, chocolate, apples, sweet cola, lots of dubbel yeasts, moderate umami, with a light bitterness.  Once in the mouth, the Calvados is pretty noticeable in the aroma.  Oak too.  The body is medium-full with a thick lively carbonation.  Lightly bitter.  Apples are everywhere.  I like the other ones so much better I am glad I didn¬ít buy more than one of these.

Schwere Malznoten sind bereits im Antrunk vorhanden, ausgeglichen werden sie durch eine angenehme S√§urenote. Dann holzige und honigartige Noten im komplexen Mittelteil, in dem die S√§urenote nun noch etwas st√§rker wird. W√ºrzige Malznoten, zum Ende dezent s√º√ü, erdig, vergorene Fruchtnoten, ein Hauch von Alkohol. Rund, vollmundig, super! 11/13/11/13/12/12

Pours deep brown with a medium tan head...nice lacing and retention.  Aroma has faint notes of black cherry, oak, and mustiness...slight soury note...brandy is present but faint.  Flavor has notable apple brandy and oak...some musty/earthy hops and mild roastiness.  Mouthfeel is medium and silky smooth...finish is dry and oaky.
black, clear, tan foam, chocolate, soy sauce, full body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness,

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2012 33 cl bottle from Barley Wine, Copenhagen. 2005 vintage enjoyed 2012-01-06. Clear, dark brown/mahogany liquid with medium off-white to tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, port, vanilla, belgo yeast, wood, spices and maybe some chocolate. Almost feels a bit vinegary. Hopefully it hasn¬ít turned bad... Taste is medium sweet, light to medium bitter and light tart/sour. Extremely complex, deep flavour with lots of dark fruits and raisins. Delicious. Almost drinks like a fine red wine. Medium to full bodied with good carbonation and sticky mouthfeel. Really good tasting, has aged very well. 7/4/9/4/18 - 4.2

2008 vintage enojyed 2012-01-10. Bottle. Almost clear, dark brown liquid with medium tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, belgo yeast, unrefined sugars, wood and vanilla. Taste is medium sweet, light to medium bitter and very complex and deep. Lots of fruit and sugars. Reallly balanced. Medium bodied with low carbonation. Really nice, not as tart and oxidized as the 05. 7/4/8/4/18 - 4.1

2006 vintage enjoyed 2012-01-10. Almost clear, dark brown liquid with small to medium tan head. Aroma of vanilla, dark fruit, wood, port wine and belgo yeast. Feels a bit oxidized. Taste is light to medium sweet, light to medium bitter and quite deep, complex and very light tartness. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Higher carbonated and more oxidized than 08. A little less drinkable but very nice still. 7/4/9/4/18 - 4.1

Bottle of 05 vintage. Pours a dakr brownish color with a tan head. Aroma is of oak, whiskey like notes, bready notes, lots of fruit esters of dark fruits like raisins and plums, spice, toasted malt, coffee, caramel and chocolate. The flavor follows the nose with oak and whiskey notes, dark fruits esters of plums and raisins, spice, a light tartness, cherries, coffee, chocolate, caramel, toasted malt and spice. The body is medium with a dry mouthfeel. Overall an awesome version of an already awesome beer.

Pours a dark amber/brown and head goes quickly to nothing.  Smell is spice, caramel, muted dark ripe fruits, some creaminess.  Taste is yeast notes, dark fruits, well blended and smooth, caramel.  Overall, I had higher expectations for this, but it was good.
Bottle courtesy of MrChopin.  Thick black pour.  Very buttery, creamy, and raisiny aroma.  A bit overpowering.  Buttery, slightly sour roast flavor.  Tons of oak.  Lots of raisin.  Bitter finish.
As Usual Struise gives us wonderfull beers. Try this one like the other, you won¬ít be disappointed.

11.2oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours very deep brown with a lacy, light beige head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, caramel and dark chocoloate malts, some dark fruits, and floral hops.  Flavor strong on all of those.  Smooth texture.  A really good beer.

Bottle, 2005 vintage. Pours a dark brown with an offwhite head. Smells dreamily of raisin, vanilla, cherry, malt, dried red fruits, caramel and spices. Tastes a medium tart, with a large sweetness to counter. Soft carbonation. Full bodied. Creamy texture. One of my favorite beers, and one I¬ím compelled to order any time I can find it.

Oh yum, long time want, finally getting around to drink more of Urbain¬ís beers. This was a great treat, 2005 vintage. Did I say yum?

Beer is black / brown with haze at the corners of the glass. Forms a good head of small off white bubbles that leaves some lacing on the glass but the head doesn¬ít stay around much.

Aroma is sweet and bready with good esters of fruits and some spice as well. Its decent volume, a great aroma.

So, my biggest criticism of this beer is that I can¬ít taste the oak, it says on the bottle that its oak aged but there is no real vanilla or tannic character, it is however good tasting. Its sweet, malty, no alcohol really, mildly spicy in the midpalate, some plums and mild raisins. Very good.

Serving type: bottle
Vintage 2008. A great 8 or 10 Belgian. Solid caramel malty body. Well balanced alc and malts, controlled nutty belgian barley. Nice tan head which has med life. A must try. World class beer

Pretty similar to the reserva, my palate is not refined enough to taste the difference. A complex beer that delivers the flavor to your tongue the way an artist delivers paint to a canvas, not sure what that means. A delicous beer.

This beer has held up very well for being almost six years old.  The pour is very dark, opaque brown. Towards the end of the beer, there is lots of sediment in the bottom of the glass.  A short-lived, thin head is on top, but it fades quickly.  Immediately the oak is present in the flavor.  Flavor has rich malt and Belgian yeast.  There is a vinous quality that works very well.  Spices also, with the cardamom present.  Some caramel and dried fruit. The palate seems a little bit thinner than some of the other versions, which I attribute to the oak aging.  This is a fantastic beer.

Bottled. Pours a dark brown with a small tan head. Getting the aroma of fresh pears big time as well as a nice pipe tobacco. Lots of spices, well disguised alcohol, wood and caramel. Warm velvety finish.

2005 bottle, pours a soda like brown with a disappointingly little fizzly ring of tan bubbles but no head.  Aroma is plum, fig, dark pit fruits, although light and thin overall.  The body seems very thin, much thinner than the standard version or the Reserva.  Taste is raisin, fig, plum, light cocoa, an undefined sweetness that could be the calvados.

Vintage 2005.  The pour is a deep, dark red color, nearly black with a fairly small, frothy, tan head which settles to a very thin froth throughout and leaves similar lace. The nose is like a fruit explosion; blueberry, plum skins, figs, dark chocolate cake, light cinnamon, vanilla custard, some toasted caramel, and faint notes of pecan.  The flavor is immaculate, balancing malt richness and depth melding with balance; still rich chocolate cake, light fudge, plum skins and blueberry, toasted caramel and pecan, faint vanilla in there, before a nice floral and coffee bitterness balances with some toasted oak rounding the flavor.  The palate is nice with a full body, nearly lively carbonation, and a round, velvety mouthfeel.  The beer finishes in a long progression with rich cake and fudge slowly giving way to the toasted oak, coffee bitterness, and still blueberry lingering throughout.  This one just took a great beer and made it much better; age and oak rounds out the flavors, the complexity only grows more, and the richness is still there with a perfect balance.  I could drink this all night even for a rich and complex beer.  Not sure how this one could be any better, seriously.

2005 Vintage bottle purchased at √∏L in Walnut Creek, CA.  There is an initially faint aroma with light fruitiness and a little vanilla presence.  Underlying cocoa notes are also there.  Nicely quaffable.  Mildly hazy amber body with a small light tan head.  Chocolate flavors are present to start, with nice sweetness followed by some pitted fruits like raisins and dates.  This finishes with roastiness and some mineral character.  Very smooth and easy-drinking.  This is a very dangerous beer.  Again, like the Reserva, this beer does not have a ton of barrel character, but that doesn¬ít hurt it.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2014 2005 33cl Bottle from Wine and Cheese Place. dark, really dark almost opaque with an initially thick tan head that dies to a thin layer quickly. Yeasty aroma, malty,some faint brandy and fruit. Super creamy full body, dry finish some light bitterness. Flavor is fruit, malt, wood, brandy, really balanced, complex and nice.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 Peu √† dire contre cette bi√®re. Extr√™mement bien balanc√© et c¬íest peut-√™tre la seule chose qui joue contre elle. Les fruits confis et le ch√™ne sont nez √† nez.

Bottle pours brown-black with thin tan head that fades fairly quickly.  Aroma of oak, dark fruits, musty.  Taste dark fruits with a bit of chocolate, quite a bit of oak, vinous notes, raisins, spices.  Full slightly carbonated palate.  Alcohol well disguised.  Finish oak, slight hops and fruit.
Didn¬ít like it as much as the regular Pannepot but still a very nice beer.  For me the oak detracted instead of enhanced.

33cl bottle from Cava in Saskatoon, 2005. Dark mahogny with a thin tan head. First thought on the aroma is mmmmmmmm, sort of a combination of red wine and bourbon. Oak, vanilla, musk and grapes, toffee, figs, rains, belgian malt backbone and caramelized brown sugar. Bit metallic/oxidization at first, disappears after it has a chance to breath, smooth, slightly tart and bitter, underlying sweetness that balances things out, full bodied, nice carbonation, alcohol is present, only really lets you down on the ending - you get some malt, fruit and oak.

2005 vintage. Pours a one-finger light brown head that fades quickly leaving some lace. Black color, no highlights, ton of yeast left in bottle. Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Dark fruit and alcohol nose and flavor is also alcohol, dark fruit and some oak, mellow sweetness. Very similar to Pannepot Reserva. Expensive at $11.49 for a 330ml (label claims this is a 750ml, I guess they ran out of 330ml labels) bottle from Julio¬ís Liquors Westborough, Ma.

Draft. 2008. Mahogony beer with a nice cream colored head. Malt and light spice aroma with light calvados. Calvados and caramel/toffee flavor with light yeast and light spice. Medium bodied. Calvados and caramel/toffee lingers with light yeast and light spice.

shared at the 6th annual Richmond Industry Gathering, 11/27/11. Nice end to this tasting. Dark reddish brown color with a thin creamy tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of bready malts, spice, honey, cinnamon and faint citrus. The taste is bread, spice, brown sugar and peppery hops. Medium-full bodied. Nice.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2012 Bottle from OL in Walnut Creek. Aroma is of dark fruit, mainly sweet figs. This beer is almost like drinking a gourmet Fig Newton. It¬ís got a full, sweet flavor of Rainier cherries and, of course, figs. Excellent palate and finish. Excellent beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Words cant describe how good this beers tasted but i will try to use them. even lacking a head this beer looked the part, taste blew me away, minimal bitterness, maximum tolerable sweetness. 
Generally a fine ale but think it is upstaged by its younger pannepot pretender, otherwise a fantastic if heavy beer! Will need to try again!
Contender of the year but no heavtweight

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2012 Perfection in a glass...This is beer on the next level. To think I have only just been introduced...
It smells sweet. Delicious chocolate and caramel flavours ooze out of this beer. It is beautiful to behold. As black as the night. Imagine crude oil untainted in your glass and you get close, add just a slight creamy golden white film on the top and you¬íre there. 
Heavy, rich and syrupy, much like the Struise Pannepot but thicker and heavier. Like them smell, strong chocolate and caramel flavours now with a hint of liquorice on the after taste. 
An absolute delight to drink, from first pop to last sip. Addict. I only wish I was a writer for the brewer as I am sure they would pay me dividends for this!

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2011 Bottle @ Exira Beer Summit II. Deep brown appearance with a brown head. Very rich candy sugar, caramel, thick woody, dark chocolate, somewhat boozy aroma. Thick candy sugar, syrupy, rich caramel, toffee, thick woody, licorice, dark fruity flavor with a slightly boozy finish. I¬íve never been too overly impressed with Pannepot and this one fell far short of expectations. It came off to me as overly syrupy and sweet and not that smooth. That being said, I still enjoy the beer- it¬ís just not legendary as I might have expected from other reviews. 2005 vintage.

2005 vintage.  Pours dark brownish-red color with light, thin head.  Smell reminds me of Westvleteren 12.  Nice level of carbonation, bit of a sizzle on the tongue.  Taste is of brown sugar, oak, vanilla, raisins, caramel, and quite vinous.  Would love to have a few more bottles of this, picked this one up from Greenville Beer Exchange.  Truly a world class beer.

Bottle 50 cl.... It pours dark brown with long lasting beige creamy head...the aroma is fruit, spices, caramel, and balsamic....the flavor is fruity, prunes, spices, dark fruits and vinous......Creamy body..... very nice mouthfeel....
Rootsier and thinner than normal Gran Reserva. Warming alcohol. Brown sugar and soft maltiness not as much as normal.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2011 Vintage 2005 and Vintage 2006.Dark brownishred color,practically 0 head. Sweet malty aroma, prunes, lots of raisins,vinous,caramel,lots of oak, plum and i don¬ít know what else ...Spicy malty sweet taste, with ripe fruit, oak,caramel, sugar and a touch of choc. Great !

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2012 2008 bottle. Pitch dark brown/black body with a small brown head. Malty aroma with caramel, blueberries, chocolate, honey, spices, licorice. Full, warming palate with perfect carbonation. Amazing sweet malty flavour with chocolate, caramel, licorice, some coffee, dark fruits and a woody dryness in the finish. Amazing. (8/5/9/5/19)
2008 bottle. Dark brown body with a minimal brown head. Amazing aroma with coffee, spices, dark chocolate, plum, licorice, honey, liqueur, red grapes. Full body, ideal carbonation. Extraordinary malty flavour with dark chocolate, licorice, caramel, dark fruits, liqueur, wood and coffee. Simply amazing.

2005 bottle.  deep brown, almost black, with a small beige head.  nose of licorice, toast, clove, black jack gum.  smoky rich caramel calvados wood, spicy black jack gum, molasses and occasional purple grape flavors.  light, airy palate similar to the other pannepot¬ís but velvety and smooth at the same time.  the palate of these beers is incredible.  aged well.

Bottle thanks to Doodler. Pours a hazy brownish amber with a yellowish brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of grain and dark fruits with oxidation. Flavor starts with dark fruits and sweet dark grains backed by caramel and oxidation.
Collonuda cervesa. Una belga de car√†cter fort i m¬íagrada molt el gustet que li dona el pas per la bota de calvados

Bottle thanks to Cam from IBS. A very big thank you for my 800th rating. Pours cloudy brown-amber with a very small ring of beige bubbles forming a head. Head quickly disappears and leaves some decent spider legs down the glass. Nose is plummy with the addition of raisins and spices. Slight caramel with a very obvious note of calvados. Calvados masks a lot of the other notes a little too much. Lots of plum and oak in the taste. Slight spices. Again there is a large calvados note right through. Alcohol is warming but never too much. A very nice beer indeed but I find the calvados to be a little overwhelming. Comes together quite nicely though and is fairly balanced. Would love to have this or the other varients again at some stage

2005 vintage.  Dark brown pour with small wispy beige head.  Aroma had some notes of oxidation.  Underneath that were hints of clove, light vanilla, bits of caramel and a small oak character.  Very subtle and delicate.  Flavors were outstanding.  A light caramel sweetness coats the palate with rather thick mouthfeel and a light warming finish.  Hints of grape and some wood round it out.  So smooth and lush.  Delightfully fantastic.

Bottle "05 vintage.  Thanks to thetomg for tracking this one down.  Dark brown pour with a small light brown head.  Dark fruit and spice aromas.  Smooth with caramel malt, raisin, spices, oak, vanilla, and maybe a hint of grape.  Just an outstanding ale...

33cl bottle.

It pours a slightly reddish brown with not too much head.

You wouldn¬ít have to tell me this was aged in Calvados barrels. It is full on with the calvados scent. I think it kind of detracts form this brew which is one of the best of all time. There is also a lot of basic dark fruit. Some of the original qualities of the beer have been masked. It still smells pretty good though.

The flavor is rich and complex. Lots of caramel and oak. There is also dark fruit, calvados, and dark malt.

I prefer the Reserva, though this is a fine beer.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2012 Donkerbruin met lichte kraag. Geur lekker, chocolade, zwart fruit en drop, apart. In de smaak komen dezelfde elementen terug. Zeer smaakvol bier, maar ik geloof niet dat het lekkerder is dan een "gewone" pannepot.

Tap @ BBF, 2008 vintage. Very dark red brown color with a nice tan head. Aroma is very powerful, fruity and strong all over the spectrum. Plums, grapes, sugar, cane sugar, some alcohol. The fruity notes seem very ripe and sweet. Everything is sweet and mellow. Lots of oak and age as well. Also some mellow coffee and belgian chocolate. Taste is very similar; strong fruits, alcohol, age and plenty of spices

33cl bottle from Discount Liquor Milwaukee. Pours a nice brown color with a thin tan head. Aroma is fruity, raisin, a little oak, a little booze. Medium on the palate with soft carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, oak, alcohol, sugar, with a dry, boozy finish. Very good, even though the alcohol is a little more noticeable than I like.

[330ml bottle courtesy of cgarvieuk] [2005 vintage] Dark brown pour, thin lacing of off-white head. Aged in French oak ¬ñ and you can tell immediately. Slightly sour, vinous aroma. Plenty of alcohol on the nose, as well. Alcohol, tartness throughout the palate. Lots going on in this one ¬ñ tobacco at the end, as well. Big bitter finish. Very nice, really drinkable [15102011]

2005 bottle at cgarvieuk¬ís - rating #500!!!!! Very deep brown/black, bubbly cream head. Smells of everything! Fig, esters, spice, raisins... Super-complex and rich. Lovely tartness to the palate that is right up my street - also hints at cocoa and vinous red fruit. Sticky, slight vinegar finish. AWESOME.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2013 2006 Vintage [email¬†protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: black with a big mocha head, thick sweet, dark fruits, heavy, thick dark malts, slight hint of roast, slightly vinous, sweet coffee, dark chocolate, mocha ice-cream, tobacco, wood, finish is warming leaning slightly  & hits you right away, towards sweet, thick hard liquor (calvados probably, I don¬ít know how calvados tastes like), impressive amount of heat for a five year old beer, this seems fresh and not aged, great stuff

Bottle at Belgobaren, Stockholm. Vintage from 2006. Black beer with a nice beige head. Malty vinous aroma, caramel, figs, raisins, bread, some spices, yeasty notes and some wood. Very impressive aroma with such a wide range of different things. Malty flavor, yeast, vinous, bready, some figs, some raisins, honey notes, some hops and yeast, woody notes and maybe some calvados. Very, very nice, a wonderful beer to sip and enjoy for a long time.
Top ten absolut. Gr√†cies Carlo per fer que una gran cervesa estigui al nivell d¬íun gran vi.

Bottle 2005 vintage. Pours a very dark brown, allmost black with a light brown solid head. Aroma is huge dark ripe fruits, chocolate, raisin, oak, soft yeasty notes, ripe plums and toffee. Taste is winey, oak, cherry, light sourness, grapes, a bit funky yeast leading to a very long duration.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2012 On draught at the Boreft Beer Festival, 2011. 2008 version in Calvados barrels. Pours a dark brown colour with no head and a funky musty nose. Very smooth with caramel, toffee, treacle and marzipan characters. A little dry with mild CO2 prickle and a long alcohol hum. Delicious! Also had the 2005 bottle at Craig¬ís. Pours a very dark brown colour with a lacy, light tan head. Aroma of marzipan, liquorice, balsamic vinegar and chocolate. Similar flavours with a little tartness. Such a brilliant beer.

Bottle @ Borefts Beer Festival. 2008 vintage. Tasted along with Pannepot Reserva 2005. Pours lovely chestnut with minimal head. In many ways, this is a lot like the Pannepor Reserva, obviously, but you sense that this is a bit more young, it has some more pungent fruit notes, and the Calvados barrel add an applish touch along with a more pronounced oak character. The taste has some Calvados bitterness, sort of an applish astringency that you often get from Calvados barrels, which goes very well with the complex sweetness of the beer.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2013 Side by side rating of 2005 and 2008 vintage: From the bottle the 2008 vintage displays a more malty aroma than the 2005, which seems to have a more acidic or vinous nose. When poured the 2008 vintage has more of the tan head than the 2005 vintage. Both have a transparent copper body. Even if the head diminishes rather quickly on both, the 2008 vintage seems to retain a bit more film than the 2005, which is practically headless after a few seconds. There is no head regeneration ability on the 2005 vintage, where the 2008 vintage is slightly more accomodating in that regard. Aromawise the 2005 vintage is dominated by caramel and oxydisation, where the 2008 vintage has a more interesting and complex aroma of malts with notes of licorice, rye bread, biscuits and caramel. The 2005 vintage is flat, has a medium body, oily texture and a tart, cidery finish. The 2008 vintage has much of the same but it seems to have a stronger body and also more of the oak and calvados presence that blends in nicely with the malt. Tastewise both tend to follow the nose. There¬ís no doubt in my mind that the 2008 vintage is by far the more pleasant one by now. Ratings given are for the 2008 vintage.


Old rating from September 23rd 2011 - Ar: 7/10; Ap: 4/5; Ta: 7/10; Pa: 3/5; Ov: 14/20; (33 cl bottle from Barley Wine, 2005 vintage) Pours clear and deep dark brown with lasting, off-white head and good lacing. Aroma is vinous, slightly tart with notes of caramel, oak and cherries. Oily texture, full-bodied, soft carbonation with an astringent finish. Taste is mildly tart with cider notes and an oak finish. Very rounded and harmonic. Girlfriend says: "It¬ís not beer. It¬ís something else."
UPDATED: SEP 22, 2011 I actually prefer the regular pannepot, but this is a good strong ale, nonetheless. Very malty, dried fruit flavour.

2006 Vintage. Aroma of apples, pears, brandy, Liquorice and wood from the barrels. Small head and a beautiful dark red colour. The balance between the sweetness and the sourness is great, just as the slick mouthfeel.

33cl bottle Pannepot Grand Reserva Vintage 2005 from Struise shop.  Pours a chocolate brown with light head on pour that quickly dissipates.  Quite boozey, tanic, dried figs, cola, candied sugar, raisins.  More carbonation mouth feel than I was expecting.  Peppery candied sugar, light tobacco, sweet oakiness, bit of a boozey bite in the finish.

330 ml bottle
A: raisin, toffee, hot alcohol notes
T: sweet, dark stone fruits, alcohol notes
A tasty beer.

Malzig-s√º√üer Geruch, vermischt mit Gew√ºrzen und gr√ºnen Trauben. Antrunk s√º√ü und dunkelmalzig. Mitte √∂liger, fruchtig nach Feige und Rosinen, aber auch prickelnd, was dem Bier etwas die Schwere nimmt. Abgangs marzipan√§hnlich, alkoholisch-s√º√ülich und durchaus delikat. Sehr vielschichtig und komplex - gef√§llt voll und ganz.Test vom 30.6.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche
Bottle, 2005 at kulminator. Quite a special beer. Very very nice, it had a great backbone of a yeast that was very refined and complex. the taste had no bitterness at all. the beer was a gem.

330ml bottle, 2006 
Appearance: Clear dark amber with a small off-white head and some lacing 
Aroma: Sweet caramel,dark fruit and woody 
Taste: Sweet caramel, vanilla and dark fruit 
Nice. We had this next to a 2006 Pannepot, this was more mellow.

330ml brown bottle. Black colour, off white head is stained by yeast flecks. Decent lacing. Nose is slightly winey, notes of alcohol, some cherries, slight woody notes. Flavour has cherry and wood notes up front, hint of chocolate, soft fruity notes. Dry and woody finish. Aftertaste is very oaky, woody, lingering dark cherry fruit notes. Full body, tight precise carbonation on the tounge. Overall, strong, woody and winey and very pleasing. Great extension to the Pannepot brand.
Bottle vintage 2005 at Kulminator. Poured small head. Slight roast with unique smooth, creamy body with yeasty aromas and flavours. Very nice.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2014 33cl bottle Pannepot Grand Reserva Vintage 2005 - bought  Struise shop in Bruges.
Pours deep red-brown  with a thick beige head
Nose: toffee, apples,  oaky, balsamic characteristics, cinnamon, ...
Mouth(feel): very gentle and nicely sweet coffee taste, with freshness and hops afterwards, full bodied and creamy. Long finish, aftertaste of apples, 
a real delight!!!

Not sure which Vintage I¬íve tried but I know it was probably the 07 or 06.  Remarkable how different this is than the Reserva or regular.  Love the subtlety and evolution of this beer.  Cola-ish, but such beautiful refined dark sugars, I would love to spend more time with this one as well... but my only state-side bottle I don¬ít think I¬íll be seeing again...

Fr√•gan √§r om denna blivit f√∂r gammal. Den k√§nns inte alls sp√§nstig utan platt och ganska sur. Mycket ek, k√∂rsb√§r, m√∂rk sirap och katrinplommon. Kroppen saknas och d√§rf√∂r h√•lls inte smakerna ihop tillr√§ckligt. Sv√•rt att betygs√§tta.

pours with low head, small bubbles, little lacing, root beer brown. Mild malt aromas on the muted nose. Thick and heavy malted sugared grapes and oak, though mainly malts. Must drink with lots of air in the lungs to tease apart the rich flavours. Complex but hard to overcome the initial cloying sweetness and "medicine" aftertaste. With some patience however, one can begin to appreciate the hidden message behind all the aggressive sugar. Still, I much prefer the Ola Dubh 30yr for $10 any day.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2011 2006 vintage. 11.2 oz bottle into a chimay goblet. Slow gush over. Not a lot of sediment in the glass/bottle.

A - Dark cola brown body and a khaki head that leaves some edging and lacing. Looks like all the other pannepot¬ís I have tried.

S - Candied figs, brown sugar, molasses, spice, yeast and a light alcohol burn. There are faint charred oak and vanilla notes.

T - Unbelievably rich and smooth mouth feel with the perfect amount of carbonation, even being 5 years old. The taste is phenomenal. Dark caramelized fruits, brown sugar and light spices. Barrel notes that actually blend in and accommodate the other flavors. The aftertaste is somewhat savory. Alcohol is slightly warming.

O - This beer was amazing. Certainly the best quad I have ever had. I drank a 2008 reserva last night and found the earthy raw oak notes to be a bit distracting. This perfected that fault. The barrel notes are so smooth and delicate and do not over power whatsoever. My favorite pannepot variation for sure.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2011 2006 Vintage - Very dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma is quite rich - chocolate, cognac, molasses. A little thinner on the palate than I was expecting, but tasty nonetheless. Taste is of salty licorice,  chocolate, caramel, raisins.

Just tried the 2005 vintage - this has a richer palate and seems smoother. Dark fruit in the aroma and taste. Very nice.

Poured dark brown with off-white head into a goblet with nice lacing.  Aromas of caramel, smoke, oak and scotch whiskey.  Taste is sweet, chocolate, oak, scotch whiskey and some hop bitterness in the finish.  A very nice and complex ale with nice carbonation and heavy body.  Very enjoyable as a sipper on a cold winter¬ís eve.

Thanks to Dedollewaitor for trading this. 2005 vintage. Pours a gorgeus mahogany though the head fissles away within seconds. Lots of oxidized/aged notes of raisins and port. There is a nice vinous acid note in the aroma but the flavour isn¬ít as acidic as expected. Notes of chocolate, oak, yellow apples and a bit of vanilla. Slightly acidic finish with a bit of dried fruit sweetness and completely lacking bitterness.

Bottle 330ml Vintage 2005 @ home
Pours dark reddish brown with a small off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, dried fruits, raisin, oak, coffee, vanilla and alcohol. Taste is medium sweet and light to medium bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is flat.
Opague black colour. Smells like caramel, sweet, roast and alcohol. Tastes roasty, coffee, chocolate. Full body, fresh and heavy.

Beige to light brown head on top of an opaque pitch black colored beer. Smell licorice, alcohol and caramel. Taste licorice, lightly roasty, chocolate. Carbo very good, full body. One to drink slow and really enjoy.
The aroma is just fantastic. A mixture of fine chocolate and coffee. I also noticed some leather tones. Wonderful!
Just about as awesome as the Pannepot and Pannepot Reserva, just a little smoother.

Small little bottle that pours a dark brown with a small head.  Has aroma of malt, and a spicy oak smell.  Flavors include some dark dried fruit, a hint of oak, molasses, and malt.  Easy on the palate due to very little carbonation, and a nice night cap sipper beer.  I wish I had more.

33cl bottle. Deep brown with some haze and a small beige head. Sweet malty, spicy, slightly oaky and vinous aroma. Lots of tangy dried fruit and molasses. Medium acidity in the flavor, with lots of tangy fruit and a light oaky astringency. Sweet but manageable and very balanced in the finish, with lingering raison and date. Decadent and silky body.  It¬ís a great beer; that¬ís about all I can say. The whole pannepot family is just killer stuff, and tis ads a nice vinous oaky component to it that I really like. Age has been good to this as well. Is it better than the others? Well, we would need to put down a few more bottles right now to make that call.

2005.  Pours dark ruby-brown colour with big creamy and mostly lasting light-brown head. Good lacing. Aroma is Moderate malty with bread, grain and roasted malt. Lots of hops in the aroma with flowers, resin and some citrus. Smells of oak and alcohol (something like red wine) too. Body is cloudy because of some sediments wich gives it a good density. Flavor is sweet with some acidity and little bitterness. Bitterness is bigger in the finish, togheter with little sweetness and acidity again. Average duration for the finish. A creamy texture of the body of this beer makes it fully bodied. Lively carbonation. Quite better than the original version to me. Great beer.

This poured a medium murky brown color with a beige head. Aroma was of thick caramel, light dark fruits, and lots of yeast.  Flavor was a bit oxidized, mainly dark fruit, caramel, cardboard, and lots of yeast and belgian spices.

Vintage 2005. Pours a very deep brown, very low off-white head that fades very fast. Aroma has a strong chocolate, mild rum nose, strong sweetness overall, light dark fruitiness late and a light touch of grainy notes at the tail end. Flavor has lots of alcohol. Early it has a slight soured dark fruity note (think raisins gone bad), very strong sweetness in the middle with lots of brown sugar, rum and plum notes. Body is very hefty feeling with lots of residual sugar and a sweetness present that almost makes the beer sticky to feel. Overall a good brew. Flavor and aroma are overly sweet with the rum and plum/raisin really dominating the flavors present. Body is good but a bit too much as for my tastes as it feels more like a liquor than a beer.

A: The beer pours much the same as all the other versions of this beer.  Dark brown in color with a reddish hint and a finger of creamy khaki head.

S: Heavy on the oak barrel aromas.  Decent amounts of dark fruit and some molasses and brown sugar.  A subtle booze note as well as some prune juice.  Faint to moderate spice notes are present.

T: The flavor has a pronounced chocolate flavor to it.  Lots of oak is there, too.  Slightly boozy on the finish with a lingering flavor of nutmeg.  Numerous dark fruit flavors on the middle of the tongue.  Definitely complex.

M: Medium to full in body with a smooth, medium carbonation.

O: Definitely good, but I still find it very hard to top regular Pannepot or the Reserva.
Bottle shared.  Aroma of malt and raisins.  Flavor of the same with dark fruits and caramel. Great beer

2006 bottle at Schraevenacker. It pours darkest brown/near black, with a thick foamy beige head. The nose is plum, cherry, fig, apple, sesame seed, soy sauce, caramel and is quite vinous. The taste is packed full of dark fruit, charcoal, vanilla, caramel, brown sugar, chocolate, sweet pear, coconut, sesame seed, soy sauce, toast, plum wine, sake, wood and finishes with pleasant alcohol warmth. It¬ís complex, smooth and well-balanced. However, I think the original Pannepot still pips this one to the post.

03/08/2010 33cl bottle @ home  2006
Was a small gusher upon opening. Head was more solid than the normal Reserva. Aroma: had more roasted malts and wood, compared to the Reserva and the normal Pannepot. Taste is both sweeter and more refreshing than the Reserva. Aftertaste: a little nutty, nice sour touch on the tongue, more a feeling than a flavour.
03/08/2010 33cl bottle @ home  2005 - Thanks to Klaas for the bottle!
Almost no head. Aroma: a little sweeter, some oranges. MF: a little less sparkling, more creamy. Taste: alcoholsweetness, oranges, port. Aftertaste: a little sweet, again that pleasant tart touch, a little mocha but not much.

Nice dark color, good lacing, tanned head... not much different from ordinary pannepot. Taste however, little less to my liking than the original, a bit too strong port taste, a bit "fat" or greasy... but very well balanced. Kulminator; bottle of couple years old.

Back to the Belgians...

First off, let me say that my reviews get tempered by ¬íeffort¬í.  When we first started drinking Belgians, all we had  available was Chimay. Not a bad thing, but it made it hard to really compare beers and set up this crazy fake economy.

Now there¬ís this and that and oh my god THIS and you have to try THAT...

(there¬ís a lot of hype) 


I tried so mnay Belgians that I was getting sick of the style. I had to chase down Westvleteren 12 because that was "IT". And then this, and then that... 

I  came to rest a few years ago on Rochefort 10. Without a doubt, the most exotic - yet full-on perfect Quad in the abbey style that you can purchase in America readily. What a bonus that you can get it in a Columbus general store for $5.99 a bottle. I can roll out to Market District in PA and get it easily. Should that decrease its spiritual validity? No. But somehow, people rate it lower because you don¬ít have to pay a smuggler to bring it in to the states. And because their abbey has not closed down sales to infidels like Westvleteren. 

I had Westy for the first time last year. It¬ís great. Don¬ít get me wrong. World class. BUT. It¬ís like selling your bone marrow to get one here. 

Rochefort 10 is at least as good AND you can actually get it! I think "effort" needs to be a criteria attribute for rating beer. as in "Is it worth the damn effort" But I digress. At many BA¬íers insisting - I sought out Pannepot. It took a LOT of effort to get one. But less effort than a Westy 12. But considerably more effort than a Rochefort 10. 

Pours like a Belgian. Looks like a Belgian. Done.

Taste is somewhere between R10 and W 12. That¬ís an oversimplification. It¬ís flat-out wonderful. But is it waaay more wonderful than R10? Not really. Is it soooo different from R10? Not really.

If you haven¬ít had it - yes you have to try it. But don¬ít break the bank to do so.

Like Rochefort 10, but a little less cloying. 
In a perfect world- if all 3 of these were available at my local bottle store for the same price - I would still buy R10.

But that¬ís me.

33cl bottle pours a hazy, deep copper amber with just a little, cloudy off white head.  Big fruity nose, lots of sherry, prunes, grappa, boozy.  Flavor is woody, caramel, prunes, sherry, red wine, malty.  Full bodied, slightly cloying finish.  Mellow, drinkable, not super special.

Poured murky brown with noticeable sediment in the glass. Small off white head developed but was not very thick. 

The aroma is complex with notes of figs, raisin, plums (dark fruits galore), oak, wine, spices, and some alcohol. Pretty nice but almost too sweet for my personal tastes.

The same list of aromas is present in the taste, albeit in different degrees of potency. It is very tasty although definitely too sweet for my personal tastes. I find it to be rather sugary.

It drinks smooth with a medium body and low carbonation.

Overall - I am not bashing this beer but I would prefer the original.
2005 vintage.  Strong caramel smell and flavor, almost no alcohol flavor.  Cognac after taste.  Great after-dinner beer.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 2006 bottle tasted blind as part of a top 10 quad blind tasting.

A: Dark muddy red-brown.  Thin skim of a dirty-white head.

S: Blend of dark fruits, figs, raisins, some boozy notes.  Very sublime.

T: Quite a bit of a boozy sweetness (very little heat), some pepper, and tons of raisins and a bit of plums.

M: Medium bodied, with a light prickly feel courtesy of the barrel aging-mostly in the finish.

O: A quality, yet somewhat unique quad.  The barrel aging treatment helps this standout.

I drank this 2005 version from a 11.2 oz bottle into my Rochefort glass.

It pours dark brown, much darker than the regular pannepot. There is hardly any carbonation, only about a quarter of an inch rises and is gone right away. Good to great lacing. 

The aroma is medium and complex. There is lots of dark fruits on the front prunes and figs, some yeast in the middle, and light subtle oaky finish. Really balanced, and allows you smell something different each whiff. 

The taste is simply outstanding, wonderfully flavor and complex. It starts off with a great balance of sweet prunes, yeast and inverted sugar like a great trappist blonde. Then all of a sudden you get this super smooth oaky finish that is surprising and great. A superb twist on a quad. 

The feel is medium bodied, and very smooth, coates the mouth and finishes slick as glass. Not much of lasting taste.

The drinkability is great, very surprised this is 10%.

Overall, I didn¬ít have great expectations because although I like pannepot I don¬ít think its on par with trappists. However, after drinking this it clearly is deserved in such praise. Great beer.

(Merci √† Viper666)  Le liquide a une robe brune.  Un col mousseux flotte sans pr√©tention.  Le nez est tr√®s agr√©able, je dirais m√™me presque fantastique avec des effluves liquoreuses de pommes et de fruits enf√ªt√©s, des parfums vineux, touch√© par un caramel chaud, fr√¥l√© par la vanille et exposer √† des vapeurs douces de bonbons belges.  Les saveurs m¬íapparaissent un peu moins int√©ressantes, l√©g√®rement d√©cal√©es par rapport aux ar√¥mes, mais tout de m√™me avenantes : les flaveurs r√©v√®lent les tannins du ch√™ne, les pommes et les fruits ont des caract√©ristiques surettes, l√©g√®rement ferment√©es.  Le caramel est pr√©sent mais peu intense.  Des pointes de r√©glisse se dessinent et flattent les papilles.  En bouche, le liquide est plut√¥t en manque de corps.  Son p√©tillement est faible et sa texture √† la limite mince.  La finale est douce, assez longue et timidement embras√© par l¬íalcool.

2005 bottle from √òlbutikken, Copenhagen. Super murky dark brown pour with a fading tan head. Big complex aroma of fruitcake, prunes, booze and spices
Sweet, vinous flavour with malts, dark fruit, wood, spices and yeast evident. A little tartness towards the finish. Fullish body and gentle carbonation. ABV well smothered. Top class.

Bouteille de 33cl. Vintage 2005 brass√©e chez Deca. Cette bi√®re est brune peu de mousse mais l¬íapparence n¬íest pas sa qualit√© premi√®re, Le nez est tr√®s agr√©able, odeur de chocolat, bois l√©ger, tr√®s complexe, toffee, caramel et une foule d¬íautres odeurs. La bouche est quelque suret (normal car la bi√®re est vielle) un peu de cidre, de pomme surette, pomme d¬íapi, touche de r√©glisse. La bi√®re est tout de m√™me mince en bouche quelque peu liquide, mais peut-on demander plus d¬íune bi√®re brass√©e il y a 6 ans. En terminant le bois n¬íest pas agressant au contraire il apporte une complexit√© suppl√©mentaire. Bue en compagnie de Patrick, merci Viper.

2005 vintage..shouldve been popped then. cola brown pour with minimal head..murky and sediment laden..very homebrewish aroma..muddled in raisin and grain with slight mineral..lame..sweet flavor with big brown sugar, maple syrup, fig and molasses..milky chocolate and hazlenut round it out. nutty and bizarre considering the lame aroma..

Bottle at Bar Volo Toronto. Pours a nice dark colour with almost a ruby like tinge to it. Aroma was sweet and of oak. Taste was so sweet and just amazing on the tongue. A little boozey, oak like. Syrup like, just awesome.

Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Deep red-brown cola body with yeast sediment; no head. Cerealy nose with caramel, malt extract, grain, and rubber cement. Toasty, cerealy body with sweet barley notes. Modest oak. I loved the original beer, but this version is clearly past its prime.

33 cl bottle from √òlbutikken, Copenhagen. Saved this bottle almost a year. Pours dark brown, nearly black with a 1 inch creamy brown head. Aroma build up as the beer warms up in my Duvel tulip glass, there is vinous notes, sweet caramel, liquorice, dark fruits, lots of good malty orientated whiffs coming from my glass. Taste is wood, we talk oak here, lots of velvety intriguing malts, slightly bitter bite towards the end. Sticky mouthfeel. Lovely beer to enjoy in small sips.

from crackedkettle.com; 2005 vintage - hazy dark brown colour with a poor head retention; aroma of apple and marzipan, pretty hoppy; fairly sweet and full-bodied, long aftertaste of fruit and caramel - velvety and dangerously drinkable though not as great as the Reserva
Wow, amazing, so tasty and doesn¬ít taste like a dark beer.  Very fruity in some respects, but not sweet.  Can totally tell it¬ís been aged in an oak barrel.
An outstanding beer. Deep aroma of caramel, brandy and spices that seems to last forever.

Bottle, 2005 vintage, shared by levifunk...thanks Levi! - Pours murky dark brown with a nice small tan head. Smell is smooth oak, warming booze, molasses, honey, light Christmas spice, candi sugar, and a bit of menthol. Taste is fantastic--one of the best I¬íve had. Dark ripe cherries, bready malt, caramel, oak, and a perfect warming finish that lingers on the throat for awhile. Smooth as velvet and well-carbonated. One of the best beers I¬íve had to date.

Bottle. 2005 vintage. Pours dark toffee brown. Nose of toffee, brown and candi sugars, plum, alcohol and yeast. Taste of toffee, plum, almonds, brown sugar, chocolate, candi sugar, alcohol and chewy caramel candy. Tasty and complex.

Bottled sample via Savvy1982, shared with oakbluff. Dark brown in colour with medium carbonation. Loads of sweet malt aroma, along with sweet licorice, stewed fruit. Flavours are of saltwater taffee, orchard fruit, black licorice, mellow oak, and sticky malt. Medium sweet and fairly heavy on the mouth, with the salty qualities enhancing this even further. Seems to lack some of the spice qualities that I really enjoy in the regular pannepot, but this version is still pretty good.

11.2oz bottle, 2005 vintage, courtesy of zathrus13. thanks, jeff! pours a hazy, chestnut brown with a thick, creamy, dark khaki head with great lacing. aroma is great with big, sweet notes of toffee, molasses, brown sugar, and rich fruity notes of red apple, plum, fig, and raisin backed by spice notes of nutmeg and cinnamon with hints of smoke and dark chocolate. flavor is wonderful as well, very fruit forward, with notes of brandy-dipped figs, golden raisins, dates, and prunes up front backed by sweet toffee, bready yeast, and hints of scotch with subtle notes of apple skins, oak, and charred cedar. palate is medium bodied, nicely carbonated, and lively on the tongue with spices and brisk carbonation. overall, a great belgian strong.

Purchased an Delirium Cafe in Brussels, and it was their last bottle!  2006 vintage.  Dark brown pour, thick tan head.  Lots of dark fruit, dried stone fruit, oak, raisin, caramel, and apple.  A really nice beer, but I still like standard Pannepot better.

Bottle 2005. Dark brown colour with a medium-sized tan head. Malty aroma with notes of liquorice, alcohol and dried fruits. Sweet malty flavour with caramel, dried fruits, oak, alcohol, liquorice and a hint of coffee. Aftertaste is quite sweet.

Pours very dark. Wonderfully unfiltered. Aroma of spice, raisins, oak, and green apple. Palate is lighter than appearance would indicate. Carbonation and alcohol give it a medium body. Light to medium sour flavour of green apples. A hint of sweet. I had higher expectation, however it is certainly worth drinking. For those who really enjoy the green apple sour side of a beer, this is an excellent choice. Much less sour than an Achel 8 Bruin.

Awesome beer, paid a good bit for the bottle but worth it.  I liked it alot. Everyone should give any one of this brewers beers a try. This one wasnt so noticeably aged being 5 years old, maybe if I would have tried a new and old version but overall great offering. Try one

Bottle shared by SpencerDB at BASC release - thanks, Spence! As good as the regular Pannepot is, this one is something of a disappointment. At five years, it¬ís likely on the downside. Something about the combination of the age and the heavy oak presence serves to muddle all the distinctive and complex qualities of regular Pannepot. I wish I¬íd had the opportunity to taste this earlier, as I can imagine the Calvados in particular accentuating some of the intense flavors. But this one had a faded taste to it, even an off-putting tartness in places as well. Still a fine beer, but not up to expectations.

Dark brown-red colored with hazy appearance. Rich aroma with vinous tone dominating, apple, raisins and yeast also comes up with some sweetness and thin warming alcohol. Excellent aroma. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is even more vinous with sweet raisins here too, thin licorice comes up as well. Aftertaste is sweet still with some yeast and some cardboard.

2005 Bottle, much thanks to Savvy1982.  Pours dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma of toffee, sweet tobacco, cherry, plum, fig, raisin, oak, some soy, yeast. This stuff is as good as I hoped. Taste is so smooth, sweet, lots of dark fruit, grapeskin,  some acidity on the finish. Medium carbonation, silky texture, medium body.

2006 bottle split with Urbain. Pours a hefty dark brown color, apples in the nose. Dry, medium body, sweet up front, dry on the back of the tongue with a slight apple flavor through the entire experience. Very nice.

A: Pours a deep mahogany with a nice tan head and a tight ring of lace as it goes down.

S: Plenty of dark fruits, molasses, brown sugar, and some wintry spices.

T: Caramel malt base and plenty of brown sugar and molasses. Dates and figs are prominent, with a few notes of cherry. Quite complex.

M: Medium body and nicely creamy.

D: Very drinkable delicious. Love pretty much everything that Struise does.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-15-2010

Jag tycker denna √§r lite annorlunda √§n t.ex 2006-batchen. Den har en tydlig syrlighet som jag inte har smakat i de andra och kroppen √§r ocks√• lite tunnare. Visst k√§nner jag igen de h√§rliga b√§rtonerna som jag blev s√• f√∂rtjust i och 2005-√•rg√•ngen √§r en absolut stabil √∂l, men lite annorlunda.

(Bottle, 0.33 l - Vintage 2005, at Man in the Moon, Stockholm) The beer poured deep dark brown and almost clear. Head was medium sized and white. Aroma was malty and spicy. I found malts, raisin, aniseed and dried plum. Palate was full bodied and dry with quite high carbonation. The taste was quite complex and also pleasant. I found apples, malts, aniseed, raisin, wood, saltiness, liquorice, dried plum, vineousness and bitterness. Afteraste was mildly spicy, malty and bitter. The combination of strong flavours worked well and I enjoyed drinking the beer from the fist sip to the last drop.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2015 Vintage 2006: Coffee and dark chocolate aroma combined with wood. Taste is very rich with similar tastes as in the aroma. You can really taste that this has aged for quite some time due to the flavour of the wooden barrel.Vintage 2005: ripe prunes with chocolate flavours, wood. Great beer.Vintage 2010: candy sugar, caramel, toffee, milk chocolat

33cl bottle shared with friends.
Nice enough beer but not my style.  I prefer the normal Pannenpot and the Tjeejus (SP?)

2010-10-30 Bottle from 2005. Pours dark ruby brown with a light beige moderately lasting head. Raisins caramel, licorice and bread in aroma. Dark fruits and lightly sweet in flavor with a slightly tart bitter finish. Also some warming alcohol in the very end. Very nice, but not as nice as I had expected.

(330ml bottle 2005 vintage thanks to blutt59) clear ruby brown with soapy tan bubbles. Nose of raisin, brown and candi sugars, sweet plum. Taste of toasty raisin, brown sugar, mild oxidation, and alcoholic. Really had high hopes on this one, but think I¬íd prefer it at 2-3 years instead of 5. It just was a bit out of balance.

¬í05 bottle generously traded to me by Glouglouburp.  The color is a murky dark brown that¬ís topped with a thin tan head.  A pencil thin frothy layer remains on top the whole way through.  Apple, cherries, funky yeast in the aroma, along with wood, candi sugar, and some light vinegar notes.  The flavor is a little too vinegary for me.  Definitely more so than regular Pannepot and Reserva and its a bit of a turn off.  Lots of rotted wood in here with ripe apples, licorice, sweet dark fruit, funky yeast, and a little metallic taste.  The palate is considerably thinner than expected.  Probably due to the extra time in oak as well as age of the bottle but this lacks the rich qualities I was expecting.  Man, Pannepot and Pannepot Reserva are both world class brews but this one, for whatever reason, fell way short.  I want to give this a better review, really do, but just can¬ít.  A must revisit.

330 ml bottle shared by lushawn- thanks again, Shawn!  2005 vintage.  Pours a cloudy dark brown color with a small khaki head that leaves just a ring in the glass.  Aroma of vanilla, caramel malts, raisins, brown sugar, and brandy.  Flavor of oak, apples, caramel malts, dried fruit, dough, and vanilla.  Light-medium bodied, with low carbonation and a fruity, watery mouthfeel.  Back to back with the Pannepeut, I liked this one better despite the body it loses in the barrels and over the years.
2005 Bottle.  Aroma of candied caramel apples,  raisins,  some light rumcake and doughy brandy.  Bloody mineral calcium tablets,  winey dry wood.  Neat beer.  A bit watery. Neat though.

2006 bottle generously sent to me by alagnak.  Pour is cloudy brown, with a tan khaki head that falls quite fast.  Aroma is molasses, cane sugar sweetness.  Behind the sweetness is alcohol booziness.  Sweet and a touch unrefined.  Taste is the nose, big heavy sweetness up front with the molasses and cane sugar, followed close behind with the hot booze.  Palate is surprisingly thin, slick and oily.  Not sure if age will further beef this up, but I was not overly impressed.  Of course, I am not the world¬ís biggest fan of any sweet and boozy beer, so grain of salt!  Thanks for sending this my way, Chris.

¬í05 bottle.  Slightest carbonation on the edges of the glass; no head.  Aroma is similar to the Reserva but the profile is tighter, cleaner.  Flavor is a bit muddied but the doughy, cinnamon spice and candied sugar pokes through.  I¬ím having a hard time determining what the extra aging and barrel work added to the beer as compared to the Reserva.  Perhaps it¬ís a slight tinge of bitterness underneath the spice that isn¬ít present in the Reserva.   Good beer but I¬ím not blown away as I was with the Reserva.
2005 bottle, muddy brown color with strong whiskey, brown sugar and cocoa aroma, flavor is malty fig and raisins, walnuts, caramel

2005 bottle thanks to blutt59.  poured a deep chocolate with a cream head.  brown sugar, yeast, dried fruits, and light alcohol.  nice on the palate, flavor is dried fruits, yeast, brown sugar, figs, and alcohol.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2010 2005 bottle from Beer Planet, Brussels. My first 5-year old ale, anticipations are high - particularly coming from De Struise, one of my favorite Belgian brewers. Pours a deep dark mahogany brown with a small tan head barely surfacing. Nose is deep smooth and oaky malt tones with hints of booze, port wine, raisins and figs. Seems a bit milder than the regular, younger Pannepot. Taste is extremely silky, with nutty flavors coming in first, only to be replaced slowly by port wine, brandy, caramel and hints of toffee. Excellent blended; this is a brew merged to a seamless mix of flavors over the years. I guess I had this just in its prime; any more taste loss and the silky smoothness would not have prevailed in favor of the younger, more pronounced vintages. A really, really nice brew from De Struise.

Bottle. (Vintage 2005)

Dark with a small, creamy tan head. 

Very nice vinous aroma with oak and fruit. Excellent taste of dried fruits, plum, oak. Sweet and a little sour. Nice big body, smooth and very drinkable despite 10% alcohol. Not much carbonation. 

A very nice beer.

330ml Bottle (2006 Vintage):  Complex, sweet, lightly vinous aroma of dark ripe fruit, malt, raisins, figs, plums, apple, slight yeast, slight wood, and slight port wine.  Poured very dark brown/ruby/magenta in color with a medium-sized, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Lightly sparkling.  Flavor is heavily sweet.  Tastes of malt, dark ripe fruit, wood, light tobacco, light caramel, raisins, figs, plums, slight vanilla, and a hint of yeast.  Full body.  Lightly viscous, then dry texture.  Soft carbonation.  Malt, dark ripe fruit, light tobacco, light caramel, fig, slight oak, and hint of vanilla finish is dry.  10%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

750ml of the 2005 vintage thanks to alen (also recently received a 2006 from bu11zeye). Pours with a large tan head over a deep brown body. The head leaves great lacing. Aroma of cherry, plum, bread, maple, and brandy. Taste is brandy, bready, vinous, dark fruits and plum. Delicate nuances. Lively carbonation with a creamy mouthfeel.

Bottle.

A - Dark chestnut and garnet color. Extremely thick, creamy, frothy off-white head that lasts a long time. Great retention that finally settles in a thick creamy lace.

S - Lots of dark fruit with date, fig, and raisin. Loads of dark toasted malt with some caramel and molasses along with a touch of chocolate. Fairly strong licorice/anise aroma. Some oak and vanilla is also present. 

T - Starts with strong dark fruit and licorice along with some Calvados flavor. Some dark roasted malt with burnt molasses and caramel provide a background base. Good amount of spice (cinnamon, nutmeg, pepper, coriander, etc.) along with some yeast flavors. Hints of vanilla and oak come out toward the end.

M - Medium to full body with good carbonation. Very smooth and creamy feel.

D - Pretty drinkable beer with a great body/feel that is very smooth and creamy. Alcohol is present, but pretty well hidden. Good taste with a pretty good mixture.

Notes: Vintage 2005. Pretty good beer, but I¬ím not entirely sure if the aging in the Calvados really made an improvement to either the normal Pannepot or the Reserva as it detracts a bit from the enjoyable flavors in those two. It does add a little something different though. This is another great beer from a great brewery, and worth trying, but I don¬ít really feel like I need to have it again if I can get other Pannepot offerings.

330mL bottle, 2005 vintage, poured into a snifter.

Pours a murky chestnut brown with a thick beige head that recedes slowly to a creamy cap with some spotty lacing.

The aroma is massive and sweet.  There¬ís lots of candi sugar and dark fruits - raisins and figs.  The barrel character comes out with some oak and booze.  Some light spiciness as well.  Wonderful smell.

The taste has a light tartness up front, maybe with cherries or raspberries.  The backbone is heavy on Belgian yeast and candi sugar.  The finish is spicy with a light tartness and a heavy barrel character - spicy oak, alcohol burn.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied with decent carbonation, maybe a tad thinner than I expected.  it¬ís a little bit thinner than I would expect.

This is another excellent beer from Struise - a big complex quad with an intriguing barrel presence - lots of oaky tannins.

Very dark brown pour thick biege head aroma spicy vanilla dried fruit apples flavour caramel liccorice coffee and vanilla apples figs and prunes good hop tastes mild alcohol flavours block out most of it finish smooth slighly dry good aftertaste of fruit spice hop and bitter
Bottle. Amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, alcohol, caramel, malt, dried fruits. Flavour is alcohol, caramel, hop, sourness, bourbon, dried fruits, oxidation. Full body. Very nice beer.

Bottle (2005).  Woody sweet raisin/prune malt aroma with a light astringent alcohol note.  Opaque brown color with small head.  Lightly sweet chocolate and raisin malt flavor with a mildly astringent alcohol finish.  Unbelievably smooth body.    Spectacular.

Bottle, 33cl. Vintage 2006 Gran Reserva. Pours a totally opaque colour with a modest tan head. Aroma is of chocolate and coffee, promising! Taste is unbelievably complex: lots of coffee (unusual in these type of Belgians), dry fruits and a formidable malt backbone that doesn¬ít let the bitterness and alcohol overwhelm. Perfectly balanced. Wow.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2013 @1stBP, Bottle: Vintage 2005:
No head.
Darkbrown to black color.
Smells like a somewhat typical brown beer.
Taste is completely different; full spiced up body, hint of malt and hops, but lot of spices, a bit like medicine but very tasty and well balanced.
Just slightly bitter, hint of liquorice, caramel and a grassy aftertaste.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle liberated from under the stairs after being imprisoned there for the past 18 months. Black pour with a light tan head. Caramel, fresh cream, milk chocolate and dark fruits in the nose. Caramel, toffee, butterscotch,licorice and chocolate flavours. Quite vinous. Good alcohol burn, warms the throat very nicely.

Bottle. Pours deep brown with a beige head.  Dark malty and dark fruity aroma with a light oaky hint. The flavor has a good balance of dark fruity sweetness and oaky notes. some spicy and earthy notes lie underneath. Nice.

2006 vintage 
head: 1 finger , beige 
colour: black 
smell: red fruits , coffee , iron, malts, candy sirup 
taste: soft bitter start, alcohol background , sweet alcohol strikes in afterwards , overflow of sweet malts + candy sirup, end is oily and salty ...

Bottle. A strong malty aroma, light alcoholic. The head is very small, beige and fizzy, very fast disappearing. The body is nearly black. The taste is very malty, caramel and chocolate, also some wine. The body is heavy, creamy and light oily with a soft carbonation.

Bottle picked up in Denmark, 2010-07-02, G√∂teborg
AR: vinos
AP: sout black body, 2 cm beige head
F: vinous, sour geuze, like that Pannpeut earlier today

Pours a dark, murky brown color, sediments continuously fall to the bottom of my pint, and the glass is topped with a nice, two-finger thick, sun-kissed tan head from the 750ml. bottle, vintage 2005, courtesy of fata2683 (thanks, Keith!): Whew! Nose of bourbon and oak through and through, followed by cabernet, green apples, pulpy asian pear (those brown ones), caramel malts, buttered toast, and wet leaves. Fat tasting, and to my surprise went down smooth. An intense ambush of malt disperses through the palate, with a rich finish of dried fruits and yeast, compounding into a smack of character I¬ím still not used to. Towards the end of my session, it tastes somewhat synthetic at times, like melted styrofoam with still those protruding, dark fruity esters coming through. Drinkability: Sinister, but consequently purely gratifying. Pairing: Two fondue sets- one with chopped garlic and Gruyere cheese, the other with milk chocolate. Rebuy: Uhmm Hm. #467 on 23062010, DG.

Bottle, vintage 2005 at home. Deep blackish brown with red glow, medium brown head, fizzes away quickly to a nice coffee cream layer. Aroma of fruit, candy, liquorice, caramel, and raisin. Flavour is a bit smokey, peaty fruit, quite sweet with mild hop and liquorice bitterness. Thick and sticky palate, sweetness fading away quickly into a lingering peat and liquorice bitterness. Very nice.

Still very full bodied despite the age. Lots of apple, pear and alcohol on the nose. In the mouth it is sticky and the calvados is quite noticeable. Still drinks really well, but not as good as pannepot. An almost entirely different beast, but enjoyable none the less.
33 cl bottle from 2005. Brown with very small tan head. Flavour is malt, caramel, dark fruit, sweet, hops and wood.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2010 Thank you Ken and Ali for this subtle treasure: Darker amber coloration with beige halo. Huge dark-malty sweet aroma follows in flavor with dark fruit and oxidation; medium lean body moderate carbonation make this much more lean and approachable than the reported big abv...plus there¬ís a counterbalance of measured mineral/low humulune hop hint in the finish.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2011 This is a revision of my original rating from 2010-04-30, when JB and TB finished med school. Now revisiting a year later as I finish. 33 cL bottle from the Kensington Wine Market in Calgary, served in a Trappist glass. Pours hazy mahogany with a tiny tan head. The head quickly fades to a thin remnant, leaving behind trace lace. The aroma has plenty of raisins, toasted malts and candi sugar, along with molasses, chocolate, dark fruit and oak. The flavour is moderately malty sweet with a touch of sourness. The flavour has a huge oaky accent. There is also a good dose of candi sugar up front and a delicate spice that grows towards the finish. The finish is a beautiful mix of raisins and spice that lingers for a long while. On the palate, it is full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and minimal carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent ale with a beautiful oaky, spicy character. It is incredibly subtle and grows in complexity the longer it is savoured. Among the very best ales out there. 2011-04-16

Poured dark brown with a small, lacing head. A quite complex aroma, with apple, licorice, raisins, molasses, hops and dried fruits. Medium dense body with low carbonation and the alcholol well hidden.

Pours dark brown with a tan/orange head. The aroma is a tad sour with nuts, plums, raisins, spices, grapes, and apple cider. The flavor is sweet and sour with raisins, alcohol, grapes, pears, oak and bready malts. It has a very vinous, oaky finish. Kind of reminds me of a very tasty fine wine. Unusual, but very satisfying beer.

33 cl bottle. 2005 vintage. Pours a dark brown color. Aroma is vinous with dried fruits and spices. Taste is liquorice, spices, some portwine notes, sour apples. There¬ís also some oaky notes. A good beer, but I prefer classic pannepot!

Vintage 2005, served from a 33 cL bottle from the Struise Webstore. The appearance is a bubbly dark brown with a micro light brown head. The aromas are sweet with apple, and white raisins, dry chardonnay, oak. The flavors are as diverse with some different variations. Licorices comes through first with apple, spiced oak, cranberry, maybe some faint coffee in the aftertaste. Not a tone of combination on the mouth, very smooth and full. Complex and delicious brew.

Vintage 2005. Consumed April 2010. A murky brown color beer with a small head. Right when I popped the cap I could smell the fruity aroma then when poured there was more fruit, alcohol, caramel. The taste was very smooth and went down real easy. By what I¬ím getting out of the taste and not having a fresh one to compare I would guess this beer has mellowed out a lot and is a very smooth and rounded beer with some signs of oxidation.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2012 Bottle 330ml from Struise online store.Dark brown color with thin not lasting head. Aroma vanilla, sugar, grapes. Taste caramel, vanilla, oak, coffee, spicy, fruits. Full body soft carbonation. Great beer.

Bottle from the amazing Struise Yeast store online. Dark golden brown pour has vari-colored tan and brown head from a bit of the black sediment floating up. Mostly fades leaving a thin film and decent lacing. Oak and carmelized sugars in the nose with very faint horse blanket and stone fruits. Rich and malty, almost to the point of comparing to a Baltic Porter. Slightly tannic, with rich and chewy malts, winter spices, raisins, leather, and smoke. This is a great beer by any measure.

Bottle. Murky brown with a thin laced head. The oak is very dominant and it only gets in the way of the classic Pannepot brilliance. Very woody, dried fruit and underlying spice/peppery notes. Dry tannic finish. A shadow of the original unfortunately.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown, smallish tan coloured head with no real lacing. Big aromas of dark fruit and port wine. Slightly acidic and very very complex. Flavours are initially sweet followed by a light sourness. Some alcohol on the finish. Mouthfell is quite lively. Great beer

750ml, 2005 vintage (oh fuck it, they all are) popped at The Penguin with Octo, Helen and Keith. Mahogany with ruby flashes, a slim but tenacious beige foam, freckles of lace. Well-spiced waft of Jagermeister-dipped gingerbread on the snout; strange bittering herbs, bark, figs, Allsorts, muscovado. Sturdy supporting doppelbock malts, obvious splash of oaky sour begging that first sip...Slick and integrated; Flemish lacto tang at the tip of the tongue melding into liquorice, creamy fig, big mellow oak at the back, gingerbread. Zero burn- alcohol sucked up by chewy malts, oak, varnished wood, stomach cramp-inducing tang. Good, but my ceremonial 3K? Not quite.

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32.  Pours a nice dark reddish brown color. Aromas of fruit, and some other hints, maybe some spices, maybe caramel. Flavor is a bittersweet, malty, and a hint of hops with a nice bittersweet finish.
Pours out black with some head. Smells sweet fruits and wood. Great flavors of the same dark fruits, caramel, wine, wood,some funk. Sticky mouth. Dry finish.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2010 330ml Bottle - Black in colour with  a tan head. Roasted and slightly fruity aroma with hints of coffee and chocolate. Roasted and slightly sweet taste with coffee, chocolate and dried fruits.

11.2 oz bottle. Vintage 05. Pours a reddish brown murky with a small beige head. Nose is dense chocolate, raisins and figs and a touch of caramel apple. Yeasty up front with big chocolate and caramel. Some definite alcohol. As it warms raisins, wood, cherries and crusty bread come out. Finishes with a chocolate bread aftertaste and is very dry. This tastes slightly wild but no sourness and not much if any bret character aside from the dryness. Very good.

0,33 l bottle, bought at Struise Brouwers, Ooostvleteren, Belgium.
Poured dark brown near black with a small, creamy delicious tan head.  Liqueric aroma with deep roasted grains, coffee and cocoa, a ton of dried fruits, plum and raisins, some wooden cask is lurking in the background. The flavor....Thick body, oily texture, the beer fill up my mouth with a high comlexity. Caramel and coffe, fine belgian yeast, dark chocolate and cocoa with roasted grains. Fantastic fruity character with plum, figs and raisin, the oak character is a plus again. The alcohol warms me up. Fantastic, congratulations, De Struise!

330ml bottle from Cafe Volo. Pours deep mahogany, capped with a moderate sized tan head. Lively aroma, with spices, pear, wood, and alcohol in the foreground, and brown sugar, caramel, fruitcake, and dark wheat present as well. Sweet malt, raisin, apple, and whiskey are the dominant flavors, with notes of wheat, plum, and wood. Finishes with some warming alcohol and apple skin flavor. Really nice beer.
sweet,dark bread, lakrids, eggs, brown, brown foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation.

First, a huge thank you to John B. for bringing this to our little tasting.  We weren¬ít quite expecting items like this...but this will do!  Poured out into my Duvel glass a solid earthy brown body sitting under a lengthy light beige head.  Perfect temp.  Aroma...mmmm...brown sugar, oak, vanilla, plummy, rum raisins...just a smidge of chocolate...toffee....damn.  Simply amazing.  Flavor has all the perfection of a well aged beer and none of the negatives.  Beautiful oak/vanilla, raisins, apples, toffee, dried fruits...just stunning.
Super rich aroma of caramelized nuts.  Very subtle barrel influence; just a hint of the vanilla.

Pre KTG tasting with oteyj and craftycarl.  
Aroma is dark fruity, pruney, a bit of whiskey, some tropical esters, 
Flavor is brown sugar, oak, whiskey notes, spicy yeastiness.  i loved how this beer reacts with the barrel.  Super smooth.  boozy, barrel and yeasty works in my book.  Yum

Very dark cloudy brown pour with a lively off white froth. The aroma is massive dark fruit, tropical fruit, oak, whiskey, grapes, raisin, biscuit, dough, and spice. the flavor is riddled with dark fruit, brown sugar, biscuity dough, oak, more whiskey, and tons of spice. The palate is supply effervescent with a velvety mouthfeel that finishes sticky and sweet. Amazing, as I¬íve come to expect from De Struise.

I really found this one underwhelming, I like Pannepot and I like barrel-aged beers, but this time around, the barrel flavors clash with the flavor of the original and I just don¬ít find it that enjoyable.  A shame, really.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2010 Poured a nice dark brown colour with a small off-white head. The aroma is slightly malty with lots of fruit; raisins, prunes. Also the overall aroma was a little sugary and had some alcohol overtones. The taste was the one thing that kind of threw me off, it is quite sweet and even a little sour, the fruits are also still present. There is a light bitter finish but ultimately this beer is not for me. A little oily on the palate fairly nice in that respect.

.33l bottle, 2005 vintage.  Pours dark and thick brown to black with no head and minimal grey froth.  Aroma is sweet, spicy, yeasty, hops and a strong oaky edge.  Taste is sweet and complex, almost smokey edge from the oak, wine like dark fruits, raisens and prunes, followed by a herbal hoppy.  Very, very good.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2011 33Cl bottle. The aroma¬ís comming to me while opening the bottle are great. Spices and apple, caramel and red fruits, some wood. Very dark, almost black colour. A little head, beige coloured. I like to get some more foam, but it¬ís ok. Specially when i took the first nip. Really good and complex, but o, so nice balanced between sour, sweet and bitterness. Really a beer to drink on very special occassions.  A very nice surprise for me. Almost like candy in my mouth. Edit: Had to add some more points after retasting. So nicely balanced, the sweetness from the regular makes place for a more moderated sweetness, with hints of wood and a nicely moderated bitter-sweetness at the end. The mouthfeel I tought was more siropy then this, but it¬ís ok.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2011 Details: 33cl bottle, vintage 2006.
Tasting notes: Pours a dark black color with a small light brown head that sticks in tiny circles to the glass. The aroma is malty with some vanilla, vinious notes, caramel, later on notes of cacao appear. A complex layered aroma! The flavor is again quite malty, caramel, overripe fruit, gentle dry roasted finish. Very complex. Perfectly balanced. The body is full, smooth and sticky. In my opinion the vintage 2005 is past its prime but this 2006 is right on the spot.
Conclusion: A very complex and perfectly balanced beer that gives you a great experience!

330mL  courtesy of glouglouburp . I was really disappointed in this. Poured a deep translucent amber with yeast floaties. Boozy, cherry liquor nose. Taste is overall very alcoholic but sweet, cloying. Really loses the magic of normal Pannepot. Had this in a side by side tasting with Pannepot, Pannepeut, Pannep√∏t.

No idea what this beer was about until I took my first smell and started drooling heavily... that never happens. Bought this in October 2008...  kinda forgot about it! Poured out a very very dark brown brew with red hues, ok sized medium tan head but it sure looks good once it boils down to a thick skim with a clinging rim and cascading lacing. The aroma is amazing - sourness with cherries, sweet apple, more sourness, oak, raisin, fig, more sour cherry/ raspberry that is making me drool hard, anise and the resemblance to a dry, young fruity red wine is unmistakable. The taste is quite sour with obvious notes of the oak, slight but early leather, very sour cherry or even beyond - maybe even just plain old sourness, sweetness can be found under that, qualities of a red wine that has sat for too long on the shelf, bretts, stiff, harsh apple, burnt sugar, weak coffee, caramel and now, near the end the first hint of alcohol burn, a touch of cheap scotch, some lingering spice that was probably there the entire time but I¬ím down to the last 2 sips ( so soon??? booo). Full bodied, creeps up to viscous while keeping thin enough not to ruin things, finishes soft with sourness, random malts (ha!) and other things that I¬íve gave up on. This beer was very very awesome. I did leave the sediment behind on this specific bottle which is a bit odd considering  my dedication to swirl everything in at one point or another.** Just drank the swirled up yeast / sediment shot - fucking excellent!

(Vintage 2006) Pours a dear dark brown with a small red light and a nice thick beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts, dark fruits, plums and raisins, brown sugars and spices.  Flavors is so wonderful, roasted malts, alcohol masserated fruits, oak, caramels, a hint of chocolate, brown surgars, some schotch and liquorice, and spices.  Good carbonation, sweet and bitter dry finish, very dence and full body flavors.  Very complex mix of flavors, wonderfully ballanced.  The feel of liquor is present and is a very warm brew.  One of the best beers I¬íve had.

dark brown pour with minimal mocha head. Aroma of dark fruits, smoke, tobacco, and some vinuous red wine notes.
